isis.stitle: ELECTRICAL SYSTEM TROUBLESHOOTING GUIDE / 9200 9300 9400 MODELS BUILT AFTER JANUARY 1, 1995 - CATERPILLAR 3176B/3406E ELECTRONIC ENGINE CONTROLS - 1994 - DESCRIPTION - CATERPILLAR 3176B/3406E ENGINE

svcprocinfo.para: The 3176B/3406E controllers provide engine and vehicle functions including:

svcsubproc.title: Programmable Parameters
svcsubproc.para: Certain programmable parameters that affect the engine electronic control systems may be changed with electronic service tools (see ELECTRONIC SERVICE TOOLS).

The parameters are stored in the system Electronic Control Module (ECM) and are protected from unauthorized change by passwords. The programmable parameters are either "System Parameters" or "Customer Parameters."

System Configuration Parameters are set at the factory and affect emissions or horsepower ratings within a family of engines. Factory passwords must be obtained and used to change System Configuration Parameters.

Customer Selectable Parameters are variable, and are used to specify operating parameters for: cruise control, PTO operation, vehicle speed limits, progressive shifting, type of engine protection system, RPM and horsepower ratings within the engine family. Customer passwords are needed to change Customer Parameters.

Since each 3176B/3406E control system is electronically programmable to individual owner specifications, the operating parameters will vary from vehicle to vehicle. Some of these parameters may cause the engine to operate in a way that the driver (or service technician) does not expect, if proper training has not taken place. This may lead to power or performance complaints and/or service time, when the engine is operating correctly.
EXAMPLE: If the driver attempts to drive 60 mph and the vehicle speed limiting option has been programmed to limit vehicle speed to 55 mph, the driver may complain of low power.

svcsubproc.title: Passwords
svcsubproc.para: "System Configuration Parameters" are protected by Caterpillar factory passwords. Factory passwords are necessary to:

step1.para: Program a new ECM. When an ECM is replaced, the System Configuration Parameters must be programmed into the new ECM. These parameters are protected by "Factory Passwords".
Rerate engine to another engine family. This requires changing the Personality Module Code, which is protected by "Factory Passwords".

Read Customer Passwords. If the owner loses the customer password, customer parameters cannot be changed. Using "Factory Passwords", the customer passwords can be read, which can then be used to change customer parameters.
Clear certain logged Diagnostic Codes. Engine Overspeed and Incorrect Engine Software fault codes can only be cleared using Factory Passwords.

svcsubproc.para: Factory passwords are only available to authorized Caterpillar dealers. Whenever a system configuration parameter is changed, insure that all appropriate components (suspension, drive lines, etc.) are matched with the new change. This may adversely affect warranty coverage.

note.para: For complete information on passwords, refer to the Caterpillar Electronic Troubleshooting Guide.

svcsubproc.title: Self-Diagnostics
svcsubproc.para: Caterpillar Electronic Engine Control systems have some ability to diagnose their own circuits. The ECM communicates with the Driver using a Yellow Oil/Water Warning Light and Red Engine Warning Light.

Caterpillar service literature refers to this light as the "Check Engine Light". This light is used for two purposes. The light is used to notify the driver that an active code has been logged or with the Idle Shutdown feature, the light flashes to indicate that the shutdown timer is within 90 seconds of shutting the engine down.
On power up (key on and engine off), the Yellow Oil/Water Warning light will come on for five seconds and turn off, indicating that the bulb circuit is working properly.

When a problem condition is detected, an active diagnostic code is logged, which will cause the Yellow Oil/Water Warning light to turn ON for five seconds, then flash OFF, then back ON for five seconds. It will repeat this until the condition is gone.
The code is also logged (stored) in the ECM permanent memory. This memory is not lost when turning the vehicle off or when disconnecting the batteries for a short period of time.
Codes representing current conditions are called ACTIVE codes. They indicate that a problem of some type currently exists. They should always be serviced.

If a fault condition occurred and caused a code to be logged, but is no longer present, the code is referred to as an INACTIVE code. This can occur with an intermittent condition or when repairs are made and the code is not cleared. Logged inactive codes don't always mean something requires service. Some codes record events and not faults.

Codes caused by intermittent conditions are automatically cleared, if after 100 hours of ECM operation, the condition does not occur again. Codes that require a Factory Password to clear do not automatically clear.
With Engine Protection selected, the Red Engine Warning light will be activated. Refer to paragraph ENGINE PROTECTION for information on this light.
